Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Lidar Investigation of Middle and Upper Atmosphere Temperature, Composition, Chemistry, and Dynamics at McMurdo, Antarctica
Award.AbstractNarration: The new observations of iron layers, neutral temperatures, and gravity waves up to 155-km altitudes with the Fe-Boltzmann lidar (deployed at McMurdo in 2010) have opened a new door to explore the Antarctic neutral thermosphere. These measurements of neutral-ion coupling and Joule heating, in the critical region above 100 km, are an objective of highest priority for the upper atmosphere science community. Development of the neutral atmosphere temperature climatology is crucial for calibrating satellite observations of the polar mesosphere-lower thermosphere (MLT) region and validating global climate models; in decades from now this climatology records will serve as the baseline against which long-term temperature trends in the changing Antarctic climate are assessed. The studies of extreme summertime Fe events and solar effects on Fe-layer's bottom side are improving the understanding of iron chemistry at polar latitudes. The vertical heat and constituent flux observations with the lidars are enhancing the knowledge of wave-induced transport in the polar mesopause region and remove the greatest source of uncertainty in current chemical-dynamical models of the mesospheric metal layers. This also led to improvements in quantitative estimates of the cosmic dust input that has implications for a variety of geophysical processes throughout the Antarctic atmosphere and Southern Ocean. The characterization and analysis of the gravity wave field in the neutral atmosphere above McMurdo are advancing the understanding of wave coupling in the MLT region and provide better constraints on wave parameterization schemes in climate models. Thus, the McMurdo lidar campaigns provide a new look into the composition, chemistry, temperature, and dynamics of the polar upper atmosphere in a critical latitudinal gap region mid-way between the South Pole and Antarctic Circle. The Fe-Boltzmann lidar has already produced a rich dataset stored in the CEDAR/Madrigal database, which is readily available to other scientists to help supporting their own research on polar aeronomy and climate. This project provides exceptional opportunities to train students and young researchers by giving them fieldwork experience in Antarctica. The project also enhances classroom teaching and graduate programs at several prominent universities around the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative project between the University of Colorado at Boulder and the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign involved operating a laser radar (lidar) at McMurdo Station in Antarctica as well as theoretical studies of atmospheric dynamics. The lidar observed Rayleigh scattering from air molecules from about 30 to 70 km altitude, resonance fluorescence scattering from Fe (iron) atoms from about 80 to as high as 170 km altitude and aerosol scattering from polar mesospheric ice clouds, which form between 82 and 85 km altitude during the summertime. More than 5,000 h of observations were made during both day and night, weather permitting, during the 5-year project. The data were used to characterize the upper atmospheric temperature structure, the morphology of the Fe layer, and gravity wave dynamics above McMurdo. The meteoric metals layers, including Fe, exist between about 75 and 110 km and are formed by the vaporization of cosmic dust particles that enter the Earth’s upper atmosphere at high velocities. Gravity waves transport the injected metal atoms downward to chemical sinks below 85 km. The metal compounds ultimately coagulate to form meteoric smoke particles, which eventually settle on the surface. The smoke particles are rich in bioavailable Fe so that when they settle in the Southern Ocean around Antarctica they fertilize the growth of phytoplankton, which helps reduce atmospheric carbon dioxide. 

The work conducted at the University of Illinois on this collaborative project was focused on understanding the impact of gravity wave-driven constituent transport on the morphology of the mesospheric metal layers, especially the Fe layer being observed at McMurdo. A comprehensive theoretical description of wave-driven transport was developed that takes into account the effects of wave-induced mixing and chemical transport processes and illustrates how these processes are related to the downward vertical flux of the mesospheric metals and their meteoric influxes. This work provides a detailed understanding of how waves impact the constituent structure of the upper atmosphere. Using this new formalism it was shown that wave-driven transport in the mesopause region is significantly stronger than molecular diffusion and eddy transport by turbulence. Most significantly, the important wave-driven transport is largely missing from existing global circulation models. Therefore, we also developed a wave transport parameterization scheme that shows how this important process can be incorporated in atmospheric circulation models in a physically self-consistent manner. When implemented, this parameterization scheme will enable the models to more accurately characterize the vertical distribution and transport of the meteoric metals as well as other important upper atmospheric constituents such as odd-oxygen and NOx, which impact the Earth’s ozone layer. 

This work has also led to the development of significantly improved models of the cosmic dust entering the Earth's atmosphere by showing how the downward vertical flux of the meteoric metals, which have been measured by lidars, are directly related to the meteoric influx of those metals. Thus, it is now possible to substantially constrain astronomical models of the cosmic dust orbiting the sun, which has important implications for the evolution of planetary atmospheres in our solar system and the evolution of the atmospheres of exoplanets in other star systems in the galaxy. The work helps provides a more complete understanding of how planetary atmospheres evolve and how they are affected by cosmic dust and gravity waves. This is but one of many fundamental issues that will ultimately lead to a more complete understanding of how life emerged and evolved on Earth. It will also help others assess the likelihood that life could evolve on other potentially habitable planets in the galaxy.
